shortLinksItems.hed: America's Top Cities for Music Lovers
shortLinksItems.dek: Blues, jazz, hip-hop, rock & roll—all are hugely influential musical genres, and all are uniquely American. Given how the history of popular music is intertwined with the history of the United States, it's no surprise that cities across the country are filled with musical landmarks, historic venues, and other points of interest. And these 15 cities are just some of the country's best destinations for music lovers.

items.title: Washington, D.C.
items.caption:
Despite its staid reputation—or maybe because of it—the nation's capital has fostered thriving underground music scenes for decades, including go-go (the funky genre's driving force, Chuck Brown, was from D.C.) and hardcore, led by bands like Bad Brains and Fugazi. Today there are plenty of places to see live music in D.C., including legendary venues like Bohemian Caverns, where Miles Davis and John Coltrane once played; the 9:30 Club has hosted everyone from Arcade Fire to Rob Zombie. D.C.'s museums are also filled with music history: The National Museum of American History, for instance, has old cassettes and other pop-culture ephemera in its collection.  

**Places to go:** [The 9:30 Club](http://www.930.com/) (pictured); [John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts](http://www.kennedy-center.org/index.cfm); [Bohemian Caverns](http://www.bohemiancaverns.com/); [The Black Cat](http://www.blackcatdc.com/); [National Museum of American History](http://americanhistory.si.edu/); [Blues Alley](http://www.bluesalley.com/)
items.credit: Kyle Gustafson / For The Washington Post via Getty Images

items.title: New York, NY
items.caption:
New York City can lay claim to being the birthplace of so much in music's history: hip-hop, punk, and disco, not to mention an absurd number of legendary musicians. Heck, the Ramones, Simon & Garfunkel, and Burt Bacharach all graduated from the same Queens high school; meanwhile, Jay-Z, the Notorious B.I.G., and Lil Kim all hail from Brooklyn. No matter your taste, there's a venue for you: See cabaret acts at Studio 54; the next indie-rock up-and-comer at the Mercury Lounge; dance until the wee hours at Verboten; or see which big names are playing at legendary spots like Radio City Music Hall or the Beacon Theatre.  

**Places to go:** [Bowery Ballroom](http://www.boweryballroom.com/);  [Metropolitan Opera House](http://www.metopera.org/);  [The Town Hall](http://thetownhall.org/);  [Blue Note](http://www.bluenote.net/newyork/index.shtml);  [Baby's All Right](http://babysallright.com/);  [The Apollo Theater](https://www.apollotheater.org/);  Central Park Summerstage (pictured);  [Rough Trade NYC](http://www.roughtradenyc.com/)

items.title: Los Angeles, CA
items.caption:
Like New York City, Los Angeles has more musical history than you can take in on one trip: Countless acts got their start there (to name a few: The Doors, Tupac Shakur, Guns N' Roses, Haim, Kendrick Lamar, we could go on); it's full of music landmarks including clubs and hotels; and there is no shortage of places to see bands play. L.A. also has an impressive classical-music scene: The Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by Gustavo Dudamel, plays at Frank Gehry's twisty Walt Disney Concert Hall, among other L.A. venues.  

**Places to go:** [Hollywood Bowl](http://www.hollywoodbowl.com/) (pictured);   [Capitol Records](http://www.capitolrecords.com/) building;  [Walt Disney Concert Hall](http://www.laphil.com/philpedia/about-walt-disney-concert-hall);  [Grammy Museum](http://www.grammymuseum.org/);  [Troubador](http://www.troubadour.com/);  [The Echo/Echoplex](http://www.theecho.com/);  [Laurel Canyon](http://laurelcanyonassoc.com/20cHist.html);  [Chateau Marmont](http://www.chateaumarmont.com/)
items.credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for CBS Radio Inc.

items.title: Nashville, TN
items.caption:
Nashville's nickname is "Music City" for a reason: The city is home to hundreds of places to see live music, not to mention a stadium's worth of big-name acts (Johnny Cash, Dolly Parton, Reba McEntire, Taylor Swift, and Blake Shelton are just the tip of the iceberg). It's known as an incubator for country acts, even leading to ABC's _Nashville, _ a TV series inspired by the city's music history. Music Row and the honky-tonks aren't the only draw: The city also has a thriving rock & roll scene, which can be found at venues like [the Basement](http://thebasementnashville.do615.com/).  

**Places to go:** [The Grand Ole Opry House](http://www.opry.com/taxonomy/term/2);  [Third Man Records](http://thirdmanrecords.com/about/nashville-storefront/) (pictured);  [Robert's Western World](http://robertswesternworld.com/);  [Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum](http://countrymusichalloffame.org/);  [The Johnny Cash Museum](http://www.johnnycashmuseum.com/);  [The Bluebird Cafe](http://bluebirdcafe.com/index.cfm)

items.title: Detroit, MI
items.caption:
Kiss may have dubbed this town "Detroit Rock City," but the genre it's best known for is almost certainly Motown. Berry Gordy founded the record label in 1959, and over the years, artists like Smokey Robinson, Diana Ross, and Marvin Gaye recorded in the small house on West Grand Boulevard. Now, it's a museum where you can see artifacts, and even stand in the studio where those musicians laid down tracks. Other acts with roots in the Motor City include Elaine Stritch, Eminem, the White Stripes, and Insane Clown Posse. (Madonna was born there, but moved to NYC before she made it big.)  

**Places to go:** [Motown Museum](https://www.motownmuseum.org/);  [Cobo Center](http://www.cobocenter.com/);  Eight Mile Road;  [The Masonic Temple](http://www.themasonic.com/events.php);  [The Magic Stick](http://majesticdetroit.com/magic-stick-detroit/)

items.title: Atlanta, GA
items.caption:
Hip-hop is thriving in Atlanta: Acts like OutKast, Janelle Monae, Jermaine Dupri, and T.I. have roots in the city, and the radio station Hot 107.9 was a big influence in getting those artists more prominent coverage. The city also hosts the [A3C Festival](http://www.a3cfestival.com/), a decade-old hip-hop event that hosts both legendary artists and up-and-comers. If you're looking to check out bigger names in a beautiful setting, head to the Fox Theatre, a restored former vaudeville house, or the Tabernacle, which was once a Baptist church. There's also the free [Atlanta Jazz Festival](http://atlantafestivals.com/) in the spring.

__Places to go:__ [Fox Theatre](http://foxtheatre.org/);  [The Earl](http://www.badearl.com/);  [Criminal Records](http://www.criminalatl.com/);  [The Tabernacle](https://www.facebook.com/TabernacleATL);  [Blind Willie's](http://www.blindwilliesblues.com/)

items.title: Seattle, WA
items.caption:
More than 20 years after Nirvana's _Nevermind_ was released, Seattle is still most closely associated with that band, and the grunge music scene that it spawned in the early '90s. And grunge fans, rest assured that the city embraces it: The EMP Museum, founded by Microsoft's Paul Allen, has a permanent exhibit devoted to Nirvana, and Sea-Tac Airport is home to a stand-alone Sub-Pop Records store. But there's more to the city than crunchy guitars: The Seattle Symphony led by maestro Ludovic Morlot hosts world-class performances, locals Macklemore and Ryan Lewis are international stars, and indie-rockers (including locals like Death Cab for Cutie) can be found at the [Bumbershoot Festival](http://bumbershoot.org/) every summer. 

**Places to go:** [EMP Museum](http://www.empmuseum.org/) (pictured);  [The Showbox at the Market](http://www.showboxpresents.com/);  [Sub-Pop Records store at SeaTac](https://www.subpop.com/airport);  [Neumos](http://neumos.com/);  [Columbia City Theater](http://www.columbiacitytheater.com/)

items.title: San Francisco, CA
items.caption:
San Francisco was the epicenter of the '60s counterculture movement, with acts like the Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane, and Janis Joplin playing at venues like [The Fillmore](http://thefillmore.com/)—which still hosts bands today. The Bay Area also incubated punk and metal bands in the '80s and '90s, not to mention hip-hop groups like Digital Underground (and, ahem, MC Hammer) from the East Bay. Today, there are plenty of places to catch bands in the Bay Area, whether it's at smaller venues like Slim's or Bottom of the Hill, or seeing the acclaimed San Francisco Symphony Orchestra play a concert at the beautiful Davies Hall. Don't miss the amazing Amoeba Music outpost on Telegraph Avenue in Berkeley.  

**Places to go:** [Amoeba Music](http://www.amoeba.com/) (pictured);  [The Fillmore](http://thefillmore.com/);  [Haight-Ashbury](http://www.sfgate.com/neighborhoods/sf/haight/);  [Bottom of the Hill](http://www.bottomofthehill.com/calendar.html#sthash.8Ojfozvh.dpbs);  [Davies Symphony Hall](http://www.sfsymphony.org/Plan-Your-Visit.aspx);  [Golden Gate Park](http://sfrecpark.org/parks-open-spaces/golden-gate-park-guide/)

items.title: Austin, TX
items.caption:
Austin is known for its music festivals: [South by Southwest](http://sxsw.com/) takes over much of the city every spring (March 17–22 this year), [Austin City Limits](http://www.aclfestival.com/) comes to Zilker Park for two weekends in the fall (Oct 2–4 and 9–11), and the relatively new [Fun Fun Fun Fest](http://funfunfunfest.com/) follows that, with more indie-leaning acts. If that's your only knowledge of Austin's diverse music scene, it's time to branch out: Sixth Street (pictured) is where you'll find a bunch of music venues (and musicians busking out on the street), but neighborhoods like East Austin and the area around the University of Texas also have plenty of smaller, cooler venues.  

**Places to go:** [Stubb's](http://stubbsaustin.com/);  [Waterloo Records](http://www.waterloorecords.com/);  [Willie Nelson Statue](http://www.texasmonthly.com/story/willie-nelson-statue-austin);  [Austin City Limits](http://acl-live.com/);  [Live at the Moody Theater](http://acl-live.com/); [Continental Club](http://www.continentalclub.com/Austin.html);  [Emo's](http://emosaustin.com/);  [The Broken Spoke](http://www.brokenspokeaustintx.com/)

items.title: New Orleans, LA
items.caption:
If any U.S. city can call itself the birthplace of jazz, it's New Orleans. Dixieland developed in the city in the early 20th century before traveling far and wide—but for fans of the genre, there's still no better place to go than NOLA. Top-notch performers like Wynton Marsalis and Kermit Ruffins (who has his own venue in the city) can be found performing regularly, but the city's tiny jazz clubs also host all manner of local combos that are worth checking out. New Orleans is also where infectious, upbeat bounce music, whose best-known practitioner is Big Freedia, originated. At the [New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival](http://lineup.nojazzfest.com/) (April 24–May 5), you can experience all of those different performers in one setting.  

**Places to go:** [Preservation Hall](http://www.preservationhall.com/) (pictured);  [Louisiana Music Factory](http://www.louisianamusicfactory.com/);  [Kermit's Mother-in-Law Lounge](http://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/kermits-treme-mother-in-law-lounge/Location?oid=1275460);  [Tipitina's](http://www.tipitinas.com/);  [New Orleans Jazz National Historic Park](http://www.nps.gov/jazz/index.htm)

items.title: Chicago, IL
items.caption:
There's a reason _The Blues Brothers _took place in Chicago: The city is a hotbed of creativity for blues musicians, including Buddy Guy, Muddy Waters, Bo Diddley, and Willie Dixon. The city is also known for house music—Dusty Groove, a record store in Wicker Park, is an excellent place to grab LPs from that genre—and its alt-rock scene, including artists like Wilco, Liz Phair, and the Smashing Pumpkins. Go to Buddy Guy's Legends for blues, Hideout or the Empty Bottle for smaller indie-rock acts, or the Symphony Center to hear the Chicago Symphony Orchestra live.  

**Places to go:** [Buddy Guy's Legends](http://www.buddyguy.com/) (pictured); [Rock & Roll McDonald's](http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/rock-n-roll-mcdonald-s-and-museum); [The Metro](http://metrochicago.com/); [Reckless Records](http://www.reckless.com/); Willie Dixon's Blues Heaven Foundation; [Dusty Groove](https://www.dustygroove.com/); [Symphony Center](http://cso.org/); [the Empty Bottle](http://emptybottle.com/); [Pitchfork Music Festival](http://pitchforkmusicfestival.com/)

items.title: Memphis, TN
items.caption:
Rock & roll as we know it can trace its history back to Memphis, where blues musicians like B.B. King and John Lee Hooker popularized the sound that would influence later rockers. The musician who will always be most closely associated with the city is Elvis Presley, who recorded at the legendary Sun Studio (now a landmark that you can tour) and built his massive home, Graceland, here. The Stax Museum, which chronicles the history of that iconic soul label (home to artists like Otis Redding, Booker T. & the MG's, and Isaac Hayes), is located at the label's former home.  

**Places to go:** [Sun Studio](http://www.sunstudio.com/);  [Graceland](http://www.graceland.com/);  [Levitt Shell](http://levittshell.org/);  [Stax Museum](http://www.staxmuseum.com/);  [Shangri-La Records](http://shangri.com/);  [Beale Street](http://www.bealestreet.com/);  [Goner Records](http://www.goner-records.com/)  heh

items.title: Minneapolis, MN
items.caption:
The first name that likely comes to mind when talking about Minneapolis musicians is Prince. The innovative artist hails from the city, and even used legendary club First Avenue as a location in his 1984 film _Purple Rain_ (pictured). First Avenue is still a popular venue today, and has hosted other Mill City bands like Hüsker Dü, Soul Asylum, and the Replacements (who recently played a huge [reunion show at Midway Stadium](http://www.twincities.com/entertainment/ci_26530702/concert-review-replacements-are-at-home-at-midway) in 2014). Minneapolis is also known for its classical music scene—notably the Minnesota Orchestra—as well as rap label [Rhymesayers](http://www.rhymesayers.com/), home of Atmosphere, Aesop Rock, and MF Doom.  

**Places to go:** [First Avenue](http://first-avenue.com/);  [Electric Fetus](http://www.electricfetus.com/);  [The Cedar](http://www.thecedar.org/about);  [Orchestra Hall](http://www.minnesotaorchestra.org/);  [2215 Bryant Avenue](http://blogs.citypages.com/gimmenoise/2013/08/tigerox_recreates_iconic_let_it_be_album_cover_replacements.php) (shown on the Replacements album _Let It Be_); [Varsity Theater](http://varsitytheater.org/)

items.title: Cleveland, OH
items.caption:
While its musical landmarks may not be as robust as some of the other cities on this list, Cleveland has one big thing going for it: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Museum, which opened 20 years ago on the Lake Erie waterfront. Permanent exhibits look at the musical history of the Midwest and Cleveland itself, spotlighting artists like Kid Cudi and Pere Ubu, as well as DJ Alan Freed, who allegedly coined the phrase rock & roll. Hey, like the song says—Cleveland rocks.  

**Places to go:** [Rock & Roll Hall of Fame](http://www.rockhall.com/)

items.title: Portland, OR
items.caption:
Indie-rock had a strong foothold in Portland long before _Portlandia_ started skewering the city's more twee aspects. Bands like the Decemberists, the Thermals, and Quasi have been around for a while, and can still be found playing venues like the Crystal Ballroom. Bands like Modest Mouse and Sleater-Kinney have now set up camp in the Rose City. The indie record label Kill Rock Stars, which began in Olympia, Washington, also has its headquarters in Portland.  

**Places to go:** [Doug Fir](http://www.dougfirlounge.com/) (pictured);  [The Crystal Ballroom](http://www.mcmenamins.com/CrystalBallroom);  [Portlandia](http://dguides.com/portland/attractions/historical-and-cultural/portlandia-statue/) statue;  [MusicFestNW](http://musicfestnw.com/);  [Portland Jazz Festival](http://portlandjazzfestival.org/);  [Waterfront Blues Festival](http://www.waterfrontbluesfest.com/);  [Edgefield](http://edgefieldconcerts.com/)

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: America's Top Cities for Music Lovers
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Whether you're a fan of hip-hop, rock & roll, blues, or classical, you'll find something to love in these cities; places like Austin, New York City, Los Angeles, and Seattle have scenes to satisfy every music fan.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: The 15 Best Cities for Music Fans in the U.S.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Whether you're a fan of hip-hop, rock & roll, blues, or classical, you'll find something to love in these cities; places like Austin, New York City, Los Angeles, and Seattle have scenes to satisfy every music fan.

fields.name: Amy Plitt
fields.shortBio: Amy Plitt is the digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Amy Plitt is a Brooklyn-based writer and digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.* She has written for such publications as *Rolling Stone,* the A.V. Club, *Foam*, Made Man, *Mental Floss*, and *Time Out New York*, where she was a staff editor. She's also the author of *[Subway Adventure Guide: New York City](http://www.triumphbooks.com/subway-adventure-guide--new-york-city-products-9781629370774.php?page_id=21)* (Triumph Books), a guidebook about the ends of New York City's subway lines. When she travels, she's on the lookout for excellent local beers, weird museums, and nerdy historical sites.

shortLinksItems.dek: Great chocolate was once the sole territory of European chocolatiers but now, startup bean-to-bar producers around the globe are giving them a run for their money. Here's a look at 10 chocolate shops worth traveling for—old and new.

items.title: Mast Brothers Chocolate, Brooklyn
items.caption: Step in to the [Mast Brothers](http://mastbrothers.com)' pared-down Brooklyn shop to find beautifully-wrapped bars of lovingly crafted chocolate, processed and made in their onsite factory. Look for simple flavor profiles that complement the bright complexity of bean-to-bar creations, like sea salt or vanilla and smoke. Or conduct a tasting of sorts with their Origins Collection, featuring a selection of single origin chocolate bars.

items.title: Theo, Seattle
items.caption: Seattle's [Theo Chocolate](https://www.theochocolate.com) has been selling its bean-to-bar creations for almost a decade. Sourcing plays an essential role in the Theo process: owner Joe Whinney was an early champion of Fair Trade, organic beans and Theo's products prove that careful sourcing yields outstanding chocolate. This Valentine's day, try their cherry-studded milk chocolate bar [My Cherry Baby](https://theochocolate.com/product/113/175), or their cinnamon-infused dark chocolate [Cinnamon Love Crunch](https://theochocolate.com/product/112/175). Live in Seattle? Tour their [Fremont factory](https://theochocolate.com/factory-and-tours).

items.title: La Maison du Chocolat, Paris
items.caption: [La Maison du Chocolat](http://www.lamaisonduchocolat.us) began with one humble Parisian shop in 1955 and has since blossomed into a global brand. Stop into one of their boutiques, which dot Paris and capital cities across the world, to experience their signature chocolates and truffles. For Valentine's Day, the chocolatier is offering a limited-edition, caramel-inspired [Valentine's Box](http://www.lamaisonduchocolat.us/us/en/product/valentines-day-gift-boxes-2015).

items.title: Dandelion Chocolate, San Francisco
items.caption: At [Dandelion Chocolate](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com)'s bean-to-bar factory and cafe located in San Francisco's Mission District, you'll find single-source chocolate bars roasted to subtle perfection. Here, the focus is on source, simplicity, and flavor. If a visit to San Francisco isn't on your itinerary, drop into their online shop where you can order their [Ambanja, Madagascar bar](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com/store/products/ambanja-madagascar-70/#anchor), which features a fruity finish that's the result of a special drying method designed to preserve cocoa's natural acidity.

items.title: Teuscher, Zürich
items.caption: Originally from a small Swiss Alpine village, Teuscher now makes its home in Zürich and boasts a huge global following. Their Zürich factory churns out thousands of chocolates in hundreds of varieties weekly, which are then shipped to Teuscher locations across Europe, the Middle East, North America, and Asia (see all their stores [here](http://www.teuschergeneve.com/Store-Locator.html)). For a particular treat, try their Champagne truffles—the house specialty—which have a to-die-for champagne cream center.

items.title: Mary, Brussels
items.caption: Founded in 1919 and the “Purveyor to the Royal House of Belgium” since 1942, [Mary](http://www.mary.be/) combines an impressive pedigree with a traditional, ingredients-focused approach to chocolate-making. Here, you'll find classic pralines, *langues de chat*, and *napolitains*, all served in a charming Art Deco setting.

items.title: Marou, Ho Chi Minh City
items.caption: Artisan chocolate company [Marou](http://marouchocolate.com) was founded by French expats who were committed to producing excellent chocolate in the same country in which the beans were grown. Each bar has a distinct flavor profile, with most highlighting just a single cacao grower from the Vietnamese countryside. Although Marou doesn't have a brick and mortar store, their bars can be found at retailers throughout the world. (See their stores [here](http://marouchocolate.com/post/55952867959/where-to-buy)).

items.title: Oriol Balaguer, Barcelona
items.caption: Catalonia is renowned for its innovative restaurant scene, so it’s a natural home for [Oriol Balaguer](http://www.oriolbalaguer.com), a chocolatier and pastry chef with a thoroughly modern approach and aesthetic. Balaguer's chocolate boxes look like they possess a technological marvel, and his playful combinations are delicious and transcendent. Try the [hightechchocolate](http://vimeo.com/2791940), a beautifully presented assortment of the shop’s latest offerings, or pick up one of the smaller collections that offer a dizzying array of flavors and arrangements.

items.title: Patrick Roger, Paris
items.caption: While chocolatiers in Europe’s capitals can tend toward the traditional and even the stodgy, [Patrick Roger](http://www.patrickroger.com/en/index.php) is anything but. At his shops, you’ll find a treasure trove of unlikely flavors like Sichuan peppercorn ganache and guava pastilles alongside classics like truffles and mini-rochers. Even more impressive are his line of single-source chocolate bars which range from modestly priced Cuban and Ecuadorian chocolates to rarer chocolates from Vietnam and Indonesia.

items.title: Neuhaus, Brussels
items.caption: Praline fans will want to make the pilgrimage to [Neuhaus](http://www.neuhauschocolate.com/index-en.htm?cu=doll) in Brussels, which famously invented the praline in 1912. While there, pick up some chocolates for your friends back home in their iconic “Ballotin” boxes, which celebrate their 100th anniversary this year. A little closer to home, you’ll find Neuhaus Chocolates at several locations in New York and environs, San Francisco, DC, Honolulu, Virginia, and Alabama.

items.title: Pierre Marcolini, Brussels
items.caption: Belgian chocolatier Pierre Marcolini is renowned the world over for his lovingly made chocolate confections that pair painstakingly-sourced chocolate with amazing fillings. At his shops in Brussels, Tokyo, New York, Kuwait City, London, and Paris, you can put together your own assortment of chocolates that are—with their array of colors—a treat for the eyes as well as the palate. If you can’t make it in person, Pierre also offers the option of [creating a custom assortment on his website](http://www.marcolini.be/#/en/eboutique/), for delivery around the world.

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: 10 Chocolate Shops Worth Traveling For: La Maison du Chocolat, Mast Brothers, and More

fields.name: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell
fields.shortBio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell are food writers with a passion for seasonal food, great desserts, and inadvisable wine pairings. Read more on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net).
fields.bio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell have been chronicling their passion for simple, seasonal recipes since 2008 on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net). After almost a decade of life in Brooklyn, they recently moved with their family to the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Virginia where they live happily near the farmers and producers that inspire their work. Elizabeth is a regular contributor to Food52 where she writes the 'Salad Days' column. Her work has also appeared online on Saveur.com, Cosmopolitan.com, and People.com among others, and in print in *Vegetarian Times* magazine.

shortLinksItems.hed: 7 Reasons to Make Mexico Your Next Romantic Getaway
shortLinksItems.dek: From sexy boutique hotels to pristine white sand beaches, there are endless reasons why Mexico should be your next romantic getaway.
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: 7 Reasons to Make Mexico Your Next Romantic Getaway
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: From sexy boutique hotels to pristine white sand beaches, there are endless reasons why Mexico should be your next romantic getaway. Here are our top 7—just in time for Valentine's Day.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: 7 Reasons to Make Mexico Your Next Romantic Getaway
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: From sexy boutique hotels to pristine white sand beaches, there are endless reasons why Mexico should be your next romantic getaway.

items.title: Intimacy
items.caption: In Tulum, you’ll find quiet, intimate, Crusoe-like escapes that’ll make you feel like you’re on your own private Caribbean island. Hole up at one of [Casa Violeta](http://www.casavioletatulum.com/)’s cozy beachfront bungalows nestled in the jungle, just steps from your own stretch of crystal clear ocean.

items.title: Sophisticated cuisine
items.caption: You might think Mexican food is all tacos, burritos, and enchiladas—and while there's nothing wrong with any of these, the cuisine south of the border has grown increasingly diverse, cosmopolitan, and totally date-worthy. Have a romantic dinner at [Pujol](http://www.pujol.com.mx/) in Mexico City, which offers innovative modern twists to traditional Mexican fare, or [Mar Plata](http://www.sanpancho.com/place/mar-plata/) in San Pancho, which offers exciting fusion cuisine in a rustic, intimate setting.

items.title: Sexy resorts
items.caption: Celebrities are often spotted holidaying in Mexico, and it’s no wonder: Luxe resorts like the [One & Only Palmilla](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/s--jose-del-cabo/one-only-palmilla--san-jose--del-cabo)—reportedly Jennifer Aniston’s favorite—offer the ease and tranquility of private island living, with all the luxe services and amenities of a five-star hotel. With their gorgeous spas and beautiful beachfront locations, [The Four Seasons Punta Mita](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/punta-de-mita/four-seasons-resort-punta-mita) and the [Imanta Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/higuera-blanca/hotel-at-imanta-resort) are equally perfect for lighting or rekindling the flame.

items.title: World-class art
items.caption: The gorgeous, gallery-studded streets of Mexico City are great for romance. Neighborhoods like Roma and Condesa are home to small, sexy contemporary art museums perfect for exploring hand-in-hand. For easy access, set up shop at the sleek [Condesa DF](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/tacubaya/condesa-df), close to the [Galeria O.M.R.](http://www.galeriaomr.com/), which focuses on the work of emerging Mexican artists.

items.title: Natural beauty
items.caption: From the lush rainforests on Mexico's Pacific side, to the impossibly blue waters of the Mayan Riviera, you’ll find no better backdrop for falling in love.

items.title: Mezcal
items.caption: Skip the dive bars and head to one of the intimate, classy *mezcalerias* that have opened up all over Mexico City. Sip on spirits made by small local producers or on pretty, artfully-crafted mezcal-based cocktails. Head to [Corazón de Maguey](http://www.corazondemaguey.com/), in the heart of Coyoacán, or [La Botica](http://labotica.com.mx/), which supports only small producers from marginalized parts of the country, for a low-key, romantic nightcap.

items.title: Sunsets
items.caption: The long, dramatic sunsets in the Mayan Riviera are best enjoyed on the ocean, so hire a board from [Puerto Vallarta Surfing](http://www.puertovallartatours.net/surfing.htm), spend a day playing in the waves, and watch the sun sink slowly into the horizon beyond.

fields.name: Ondine Cohane
fields.shortBio: Contributing editor [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) is based in Tuscany—when not doing a round-the-world trip each winter.
fields.bio: After [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) edited *Conde Nast Traveler's* Word of Mouth section for a couple of years, she got her dream job, a gig as a contributing editor at the magazine. Eating great food, drinking excellent wine, discovering small hotels, exploring far-flung destinations are all part of the gig, and what she loves. Ondine was previously at *New York* magazine, and frequently writes for *The New York Times* travel section as well as *Lonny, Details,* and other magazines. Before Columbia College and Brearley, Ondine's family moved every couple of years, which may partially explain the wanderlust.

featureContentItems.hed: America's Top Cities for Music Lovers
featureContentItems.dek: Blues, jazz, hip-hop, rock & roll—all are hugely influential musical genres, and all are uniquely American. Given how the history of popular music is intertwined with the history of the United States, it's no surprise that cities across the country are filled with musical landmarks, historic venues, and other points of interest. And these 15 cities are just some of the country's best destinations for music lovers.

items.title: Washington, D.C.
items.caption:
Despite its staid reputation—or maybe because of it—the nation's capital has fostered thriving underground music scenes for decades, including go-go (the funky genre's driving force, Chuck Brown, was from D.C.) and hardcore, led by bands like Bad Brains and Fugazi. Today there are plenty of places to see live music in D.C., including legendary venues like Bohemian Caverns, where Miles Davis and John Coltrane once played; the 9:30 Club has hosted everyone from Arcade Fire to Rob Zombie. D.C.'s museums are also filled with music history: The National Museum of American History, for instance, has old cassettes and other pop-culture ephemera in its collection.  

**Places to go:** [The 9:30 Club](http://www.930.com/) (pictured); [John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts](http://www.kennedy-center.org/index.cfm); [Bohemian Caverns](http://www.bohemiancaverns.com/); [The Black Cat](http://www.blackcatdc.com/); [National Museum of American History](http://americanhistory.si.edu/); [Blues Alley](http://www.bluesalley.com/)
items.credit: Kyle Gustafson / For The Washington Post via Getty Images

items.title: New York, NY
items.caption:
New York City can lay claim to being the birthplace of so much in music's history: hip-hop, punk, and disco, not to mention an absurd number of legendary musicians. Heck, the Ramones, Simon & Garfunkel, and Burt Bacharach all graduated from the same Queens high school; meanwhile, Jay-Z, the Notorious B.I.G., and Lil Kim all hail from Brooklyn. No matter your taste, there's a venue for you: See cabaret acts at Studio 54; the next indie-rock up-and-comer at the Mercury Lounge; dance until the wee hours at Verboten; or see which big names are playing at legendary spots like Radio City Music Hall or the Beacon Theatre.  

**Places to go:** [Bowery Ballroom](http://www.boweryballroom.com/);  [Metropolitan Opera House](http://www.metopera.org/);  [The Town Hall](http://thetownhall.org/);  [Blue Note](http://www.bluenote.net/newyork/index.shtml);  [Baby's All Right](http://babysallright.com/);  [The Apollo Theater](https://www.apollotheater.org/);  Central Park Summerstage (pictured);  [Rough Trade NYC](http://www.roughtradenyc.com/)

items.title: Los Angeles, CA
items.caption:
Like New York City, Los Angeles has more musical history than you can take in on one trip: Countless acts got their start there (to name a few: The Doors, Tupac Shakur, Guns N' Roses, Haim, Kendrick Lamar, we could go on); it's full of music landmarks including clubs and hotels; and there is no shortage of places to see bands play. L.A. also has an impressive classical-music scene: The Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by Gustavo Dudamel, plays at Frank Gehry's twisty Walt Disney Concert Hall, among other L.A. venues.  

**Places to go:** [Hollywood Bowl](http://www.hollywoodbowl.com/) (pictured);   [Capitol Records](http://www.capitolrecords.com/) building;  [Walt Disney Concert Hall](http://www.laphil.com/philpedia/about-walt-disney-concert-hall);  [Grammy Museum](http://www.grammymuseum.org/);  [Troubador](http://www.troubadour.com/);  [The Echo/Echoplex](http://www.theecho.com/);  [Laurel Canyon](http://laurelcanyonassoc.com/20cHist.html);  [Chateau Marmont](http://www.chateaumarmont.com/)
items.credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for CBS Radio Inc.

items.title: Nashville, TN
items.caption:
Nashville's nickname is "Music City" for a reason: The city is home to hundreds of places to see live music, not to mention a stadium's worth of big-name acts (Johnny Cash, Dolly Parton, Reba McEntire, Taylor Swift, and Blake Shelton are just the tip of the iceberg). It's known as an incubator for country acts, even leading to ABC's _Nashville, _ a TV series inspired by the city's music history. Music Row and the honky-tonks aren't the only draw: The city also has a thriving rock & roll scene, which can be found at venues like [the Basement](http://thebasementnashville.do615.com/).  

**Places to go:** [The Grand Ole Opry House](http://www.opry.com/taxonomy/term/2);  [Third Man Records](http://thirdmanrecords.com/about/nashville-storefront/) (pictured);  [Robert's Western World](http://robertswesternworld.com/);  [Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum](http://countrymusichalloffame.org/);  [The Johnny Cash Museum](http://www.johnnycashmuseum.com/);  [The Bluebird Cafe](http://bluebirdcafe.com/index.cfm)

items.title: Detroit, MI
items.caption:
Kiss may have dubbed this town "Detroit Rock City," but the genre it's best known for is almost certainly Motown. Berry Gordy founded the record label in 1959, and over the years, artists like Smokey Robinson, Diana Ross, and Marvin Gaye recorded in the small house on West Grand Boulevard. Now, it's a museum where you can see artifacts, and even stand in the studio where those musicians laid down tracks. Other acts with roots in the Motor City include Elaine Stritch, Eminem, the White Stripes, and Insane Clown Posse. (Madonna was born there, but moved to NYC before she made it big.)  

**Places to go:** [Motown Museum](https://www.motownmuseum.org/);  [Cobo Center](http://www.cobocenter.com/);  Eight Mile Road;  [The Masonic Temple](http://www.themasonic.com/events.php);  [The Magic Stick](http://majesticdetroit.com/magic-stick-detroit/)

items.title: Atlanta, GA
items.caption:
Hip-hop is thriving in Atlanta: Acts like OutKast, Janelle Monae, Jermaine Dupri, and T.I. have roots in the city, and the radio station Hot 107.9 was a big influence in getting those artists more prominent coverage. The city also hosts the [A3C Festival](http://www.a3cfestival.com/), a decade-old hip-hop event that hosts both legendary artists and up-and-comers. If you're looking to check out bigger names in a beautiful setting, head to the Fox Theatre, a restored former vaudeville house, or the Tabernacle, which was once a Baptist church. There's also the free [Atlanta Jazz Festival](http://atlantafestivals.com/) in the spring.

__Places to go:__ [Fox Theatre](http://foxtheatre.org/);  [The Earl](http://www.badearl.com/);  [Criminal Records](http://www.criminalatl.com/);  [The Tabernacle](https://www.facebook.com/TabernacleATL);  [Blind Willie's](http://www.blindwilliesblues.com/)

items.title: Seattle, WA
items.caption:
More than 20 years after Nirvana's _Nevermind_ was released, Seattle is still most closely associated with that band, and the grunge music scene that it spawned in the early '90s. And grunge fans, rest assured that the city embraces it: The EMP Museum, founded by Microsoft's Paul Allen, has a permanent exhibit devoted to Nirvana, and Sea-Tac Airport is home to a stand-alone Sub-Pop Records store. But there's more to the city than crunchy guitars: The Seattle Symphony led by maestro Ludovic Morlot hosts world-class performances, locals Macklemore and Ryan Lewis are international stars, and indie-rockers (including locals like Death Cab for Cutie) can be found at the [Bumbershoot Festival](http://bumbershoot.org/) every summer. 

**Places to go:** [EMP Museum](http://www.empmuseum.org/) (pictured);  [The Showbox at the Market](http://www.showboxpresents.com/);  [Sub-Pop Records store at SeaTac](https://www.subpop.com/airport);  [Neumos](http://neumos.com/);  [Columbia City Theater](http://www.columbiacitytheater.com/)

items.title: San Francisco, CA
items.caption:
San Francisco was the epicenter of the '60s counterculture movement, with acts like the Grateful Dead, Jefferson Airplane, and Janis Joplin playing at venues like [The Fillmore](http://thefillmore.com/)—which still hosts bands today. The Bay Area also incubated punk and metal bands in the '80s and '90s, not to mention hip-hop groups like Digital Underground (and, ahem, MC Hammer) from the East Bay. Today, there are plenty of places to catch bands in the Bay Area, whether it's at smaller venues like Slim's or Bottom of the Hill, or seeing the acclaimed San Francisco Symphony Orchestra play a concert at the beautiful Davies Hall. Don't miss the amazing Amoeba Music outpost on Telegraph Avenue in Berkeley.  

**Places to go:** [Amoeba Music](http://www.amoeba.com/) (pictured);  [The Fillmore](http://thefillmore.com/);  [Haight-Ashbury](http://www.sfgate.com/neighborhoods/sf/haight/);  [Bottom of the Hill](http://www.bottomofthehill.com/calendar.html#sthash.8Ojfozvh.dpbs);  [Davies Symphony Hall](http://www.sfsymphony.org/Plan-Your-Visit.aspx);  [Golden Gate Park](http://sfrecpark.org/parks-open-spaces/golden-gate-park-guide/)

items.title: Austin, TX
items.caption:
Austin is known for its music festivals: [South by Southwest](http://sxsw.com/) takes over much of the city every spring (March 17–22 this year), [Austin City Limits](http://www.aclfestival.com/) comes to Zilker Park for two weekends in the fall (Oct 2–4 and 9–11), and the relatively new [Fun Fun Fun Fest](http://funfunfunfest.com/) follows that, with more indie-leaning acts. If that's your only knowledge of Austin's diverse music scene, it's time to branch out: Sixth Street (pictured) is where you'll find a bunch of music venues (and musicians busking out on the street), but neighborhoods like East Austin and the area around the University of Texas also have plenty of smaller, cooler venues.  

**Places to go:** [Stubb's](http://stubbsaustin.com/);  [Waterloo Records](http://www.waterloorecords.com/);  [Willie Nelson Statue](http://www.texasmonthly.com/story/willie-nelson-statue-austin);  [Austin City Limits](http://acl-live.com/);  [Live at the Moody Theater](http://acl-live.com/); [Continental Club](http://www.continentalclub.com/Austin.html);  [Emo's](http://emosaustin.com/);  [The Broken Spoke](http://www.brokenspokeaustintx.com/)

items.title: New Orleans, LA
items.caption:
If any U.S. city can call itself the birthplace of jazz, it's New Orleans. Dixieland developed in the city in the early 20th century before traveling far and wide—but for fans of the genre, there's still no better place to go than NOLA. Top-notch performers like Wynton Marsalis and Kermit Ruffins (who has his own venue in the city) can be found performing regularly, but the city's tiny jazz clubs also host all manner of local combos that are worth checking out. New Orleans is also where infectious, upbeat bounce music, whose best-known practitioner is Big Freedia, originated. At the [New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival](http://lineup.nojazzfest.com/) (April 24–May 5), you can experience all of those different performers in one setting.  

**Places to go:** [Preservation Hall](http://www.preservationhall.com/) (pictured);  [Louisiana Music Factory](http://www.louisianamusicfactory.com/);  [Kermit's Mother-in-Law Lounge](http://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/kermits-treme-mother-in-law-lounge/Location?oid=1275460);  [Tipitina's](http://www.tipitinas.com/);  [New Orleans Jazz National Historic Park](http://www.nps.gov/jazz/index.htm)

items.title: Chicago, IL
items.caption:
There's a reason _The Blues Brothers _took place in Chicago: The city is a hotbed of creativity for blues musicians, including Buddy Guy, Muddy Waters, Bo Diddley, and Willie Dixon. The city is also known for house music—Dusty Groove, a record store in Wicker Park, is an excellent place to grab LPs from that genre—and its alt-rock scene, including artists like Wilco, Liz Phair, and the Smashing Pumpkins. Go to Buddy Guy's Legends for blues, Hideout or the Empty Bottle for smaller indie-rock acts, or the Symphony Center to hear the Chicago Symphony Orchestra live.  

**Places to go:** [Buddy Guy's Legends](http://www.buddyguy.com/) (pictured); [Rock & Roll McDonald's](http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/rock-n-roll-mcdonald-s-and-museum); [The Metro](http://metrochicago.com/); [Reckless Records](http://www.reckless.com/); Willie Dixon's Blues Heaven Foundation; [Dusty Groove](https://www.dustygroove.com/); [Symphony Center](http://cso.org/); [the Empty Bottle](http://emptybottle.com/); [Pitchfork Music Festival](http://pitchforkmusicfestival.com/)

items.title: Memphis, TN
items.caption:
Rock & roll as we know it can trace its history back to Memphis, where blues musicians like B.B. King and John Lee Hooker popularized the sound that would influence later rockers. The musician who will always be most closely associated with the city is Elvis Presley, who recorded at the legendary Sun Studio (now a landmark that you can tour) and built his massive home, Graceland, here. The Stax Museum, which chronicles the history of that iconic soul label (home to artists like Otis Redding, Booker T. & the MG's, and Isaac Hayes), is located at the label's former home.  

**Places to go:** [Sun Studio](http://www.sunstudio.com/);  [Graceland](http://www.graceland.com/);  [Levitt Shell](http://levittshell.org/);  [Stax Museum](http://www.staxmuseum.com/);  [Shangri-La Records](http://shangri.com/);  [Beale Street](http://www.bealestreet.com/);  [Goner Records](http://www.goner-records.com/)  heh

items.title: Minneapolis, MN
items.caption:
The first name that likely comes to mind when talking about Minneapolis musicians is Prince. The innovative artist hails from the city, and even used legendary club First Avenue as a location in his 1984 film _Purple Rain_ (pictured). First Avenue is still a popular venue today, and has hosted other Mill City bands like Hüsker Dü, Soul Asylum, and the Replacements (who recently played a huge [reunion show at Midway Stadium](http://www.twincities.com/entertainment/ci_26530702/concert-review-replacements-are-at-home-at-midway) in 2014). Minneapolis is also known for its classical music scene—notably the Minnesota Orchestra—as well as rap label [Rhymesayers](http://www.rhymesayers.com/), home of Atmosphere, Aesop Rock, and MF Doom.  

**Places to go:** [First Avenue](http://first-avenue.com/);  [Electric Fetus](http://www.electricfetus.com/);  [The Cedar](http://www.thecedar.org/about);  [Orchestra Hall](http://www.minnesotaorchestra.org/);  [2215 Bryant Avenue](http://blogs.citypages.com/gimmenoise/2013/08/tigerox_recreates_iconic_let_it_be_album_cover_replacements.php) (shown on the Replacements album _Let It Be_); [Varsity Theater](http://varsitytheater.org/)

items.title: Cleveland, OH
items.caption:
While its musical landmarks may not be as robust as some of the other cities on this list, Cleveland has one big thing going for it: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame Museum, which opened 20 years ago on the Lake Erie waterfront. Permanent exhibits look at the musical history of the Midwest and Cleveland itself, spotlighting artists like Kid Cudi and Pere Ubu, as well as DJ Alan Freed, who allegedly coined the phrase rock & roll. Hey, like the song says—Cleveland rocks.  

**Places to go:** [Rock & Roll Hall of Fame](http://www.rockhall.com/)

items.title: Portland, OR
items.caption:
Indie-rock had a strong foothold in Portland long before _Portlandia_ started skewering the city's more twee aspects. Bands like the Decemberists, the Thermals, and Quasi have been around for a while, and can still be found playing venues like the Crystal Ballroom. Bands like Modest Mouse and Sleater-Kinney have now set up camp in the Rose City. The indie record label Kill Rock Stars, which began in Olympia, Washington, also has its headquarters in Portland.  

**Places to go:** [Doug Fir](http://www.dougfirlounge.com/) (pictured);  [The Crystal Ballroom](http://www.mcmenamins.com/CrystalBallroom);  [Portlandia](http://dguides.com/portland/attractions/historical-and-cultural/portlandia-statue/) statue;  [MusicFestNW](http://musicfestnw.com/);  [Portland Jazz Festival](http://portlandjazzfestival.org/);  [Waterfront Blues Festival](http://www.waterfrontbluesfest.com/);  [Edgefield](http://edgefieldconcerts.com/)

featureContentItems.seoTitle: America's Top Cities for Music Lovers
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Whether you're a fan of hip-hop, rock & roll, blues, or classical, you'll find something to love in these cities; places like Austin, New York City, Los Angeles, and Seattle have scenes to satisfy every music fan.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: The 15 Best Cities for Music Fans in the U.S.
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Whether you're a fan of hip-hop, rock & roll, blues, or classical, you'll find something to love in these cities; places like Austin, New York City, Los Angeles, and Seattle have scenes to satisfy every music fan.

fields.name: Amy Plitt
fields.shortBio: Amy Plitt is the digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Amy Plitt is a Brooklyn-based writer and digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.* She has written for such publications as *Rolling Stone,* the A.V. Club, *Foam*, Made Man, *Mental Floss*, and *Time Out New York*, where she was a staff editor. She's also the author of *[Subway Adventure Guide: New York City](http://www.triumphbooks.com/subway-adventure-guide--new-york-city-products-9781629370774.php?page_id=21)* (Triumph Books), a guidebook about the ends of New York City's subway lines. When she travels, she's on the lookout for excellent local beers, weird museums, and nerdy historical sites.

featureContentItems.dek: Temples are a frequent site on any trip to Asia, but these are the most beautiful, most historic, and most unmissable stupas to put on your list.

items.title: Ruwanwelisaya
items.caption:
Built by King Dutugemunu in the second century B.C., Ruwanwelisaya underwent renovations in 1837 that gave the structure's dome its current flattened shape.




[See the complete Sri Lanka itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/sri-lanka)

items.title: The Great Stupa at Sanchi
items.caption:
The Great Stupa at Sanchi—believed to house a relic of the Buddha—is one of the stone marvels of the ancient world.




[See the complete India itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/india)

items.title: Swayambunath Stupa
items.caption:
Considered the most powerful shrine in the Himalayan region, Swayambhunath Stupa (the name means "self-manifested") is built in the classic Nepali style. The white dome represents earth; the 13 tiers of the spire are the stages man must pass through to reach nirvana.




[See the complete Nepal itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/nepal)

items.title: Chorten Kora
items.caption:
Chorten Kora is one of the most important religious sites in the country. Built in 1740 on the banks of the Kolung Chu River, the place is unique in that most chortens are on trails or at mountain passes.









[See the complete Bhutan itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/bhutan)

items.title: Shwedagon Pagoda
items.caption:
Adorned in diamonds, Rangoon's gilded Shwedagon Pagoda is said to house the Buddha's hair and other relics.




[See the complete Burma itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/burma)

items.title: Tháp Rùa
items.caption:
Located in the middle of Hanoi's Hoan Kiem Lake, Tháp Rùa, or Turtle Stupa, is a symbol of the city and Vietnam's pagoda stupa style.




[See the complete Vietnam itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/vietnam)

items.title: Wat Phnom
items.caption:
According to legend, a 14th-century woman found four bronze images of the Buddha inside a huge _koki_ tree growing in the river, and Wat Phnom was built to house them.




[See the complete Cambodia itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/cambodia)

items.title: Phra Pathom Chedi
items.caption:
Said to house some of the Buddha's original relics, central Thailand's Phra Pathom Chedi is, at 417 feet high, considered the tallest stupa in the world.




[See the complete Thailand itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/thailand)

items.title: Sairira Stupa
items.caption:
Due to the country's diverse Buddhist origins, Singapore's stupas and temples take on a number of architectural forms, though most are variations on the dome style. One such example is Sairira Stupa at Kong Meng San Phor Kark See Monastery.




[See the complete Singapore itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/singapore)

items.title: Brahma Vihara Arama
items.caption:
Religious monuments in Bali tend to be influenced by the island's Hindu roots. Still, most stupas are of the bell-shaped variety, like those found at Brahma Vihara Arama, which are modeled after Java's famous Borobudur temple complex.




[See the complete Bali itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/bali)

items.title: Pagoda Forest
items.caption:
Perched in the mountains of Shaolin, the birthplace of kung fu and the home of the famous fighting monks, you'll find the Pagoda Forest. Its hundreds of terraced stupas contain monuments from the ninth to nineteenth centuries.




[See the complete China itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/china)

items.title: Gotemba Stupa
items.caption:
The Gotemba Stupa, said to house some of the Buddha's ashes, is the crown jewel of the Peace Park in Shizuoka.




[See the complete Japan itinerary](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia/japan)

featureContentItems.dek: Great chocolate was once the sole territory of European chocolatiers but now, startup bean-to-bar producers around the globe are giving them a run for their money. Here's a look at 10 chocolate shops worth traveling for—old and new.

items.title: Mast Brothers Chocolate, Brooklyn
items.caption: Step in to the [Mast Brothers](http://mastbrothers.com)' pared-down Brooklyn shop to find beautifully-wrapped bars of lovingly crafted chocolate, processed and made in their onsite factory. Look for simple flavor profiles that complement the bright complexity of bean-to-bar creations, like sea salt or vanilla and smoke. Or conduct a tasting of sorts with their Origins Collection, featuring a selection of single origin chocolate bars.

items.title: Theo, Seattle
items.caption: Seattle's [Theo Chocolate](https://www.theochocolate.com) has been selling its bean-to-bar creations for almost a decade. Sourcing plays an essential role in the Theo process: owner Joe Whinney was an early champion of Fair Trade, organic beans and Theo's products prove that careful sourcing yields outstanding chocolate. This Valentine's day, try their cherry-studded milk chocolate bar [My Cherry Baby](https://theochocolate.com/product/113/175), or their cinnamon-infused dark chocolate [Cinnamon Love Crunch](https://theochocolate.com/product/112/175). Live in Seattle? Tour their [Fremont factory](https://theochocolate.com/factory-and-tours).

items.title: La Maison du Chocolat, Paris
items.caption: [La Maison du Chocolat](http://www.lamaisonduchocolat.us) began with one humble Parisian shop in 1955 and has since blossomed into a global brand. Stop into one of their boutiques, which dot Paris and capital cities across the world, to experience their signature chocolates and truffles. For Valentine's Day, the chocolatier is offering a limited-edition, caramel-inspired [Valentine's Box](http://www.lamaisonduchocolat.us/us/en/product/valentines-day-gift-boxes-2015).

items.title: Dandelion Chocolate, San Francisco
items.caption: At [Dandelion Chocolate](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com)'s bean-to-bar factory and cafe located in San Francisco's Mission District, you'll find single-source chocolate bars roasted to subtle perfection. Here, the focus is on source, simplicity, and flavor. If a visit to San Francisco isn't on your itinerary, drop into their online shop where you can order their [Ambanja, Madagascar bar](http://www.dandelionchocolate.com/store/products/ambanja-madagascar-70/#anchor), which features a fruity finish that's the result of a special drying method designed to preserve cocoa's natural acidity.

items.title: Teuscher, Zürich
items.caption: Originally from a small Swiss Alpine village, Teuscher now makes its home in Zürich and boasts a huge global following. Their Zürich factory churns out thousands of chocolates in hundreds of varieties weekly, which are then shipped to Teuscher locations across Europe, the Middle East, North America, and Asia (see all their stores [here](http://www.teuschergeneve.com/Store-Locator.html)). For a particular treat, try their Champagne truffles—the house specialty—which have a to-die-for champagne cream center.

items.title: Mary, Brussels
items.caption: Founded in 1919 and the “Purveyor to the Royal House of Belgium” since 1942, [Mary](http://www.mary.be/) combines an impressive pedigree with a traditional, ingredients-focused approach to chocolate-making. Here, you'll find classic pralines, *langues de chat*, and *napolitains*, all served in a charming Art Deco setting.

items.title: Marou, Ho Chi Minh City
items.caption: Artisan chocolate company [Marou](http://marouchocolate.com) was founded by French expats who were committed to producing excellent chocolate in the same country in which the beans were grown. Each bar has a distinct flavor profile, with most highlighting just a single cacao grower from the Vietnamese countryside. Although Marou doesn't have a brick and mortar store, their bars can be found at retailers throughout the world. (See their stores [here](http://marouchocolate.com/post/55952867959/where-to-buy)).

items.title: Oriol Balaguer, Barcelona
items.caption: Catalonia is renowned for its innovative restaurant scene, so it’s a natural home for [Oriol Balaguer](http://www.oriolbalaguer.com), a chocolatier and pastry chef with a thoroughly modern approach and aesthetic. Balaguer's chocolate boxes look like they possess a technological marvel, and his playful combinations are delicious and transcendent. Try the [hightechchocolate](http://vimeo.com/2791940), a beautifully presented assortment of the shop’s latest offerings, or pick up one of the smaller collections that offer a dizzying array of flavors and arrangements.

items.title: Patrick Roger, Paris
items.caption: While chocolatiers in Europe’s capitals can tend toward the traditional and even the stodgy, [Patrick Roger](http://www.patrickroger.com/en/index.php) is anything but. At his shops, you’ll find a treasure trove of unlikely flavors like Sichuan peppercorn ganache and guava pastilles alongside classics like truffles and mini-rochers. Even more impressive are his line of single-source chocolate bars which range from modestly priced Cuban and Ecuadorian chocolates to rarer chocolates from Vietnam and Indonesia.

items.title: Neuhaus, Brussels
items.caption: Praline fans will want to make the pilgrimage to [Neuhaus](http://www.neuhauschocolate.com/index-en.htm?cu=doll) in Brussels, which famously invented the praline in 1912. While there, pick up some chocolates for your friends back home in their iconic “Ballotin” boxes, which celebrate their 100th anniversary this year. A little closer to home, you’ll find Neuhaus Chocolates at several locations in New York and environs, San Francisco, DC, Honolulu, Virginia, and Alabama.

items.title: Pierre Marcolini, Brussels
items.caption: Belgian chocolatier Pierre Marcolini is renowned the world over for his lovingly made chocolate confections that pair painstakingly-sourced chocolate with amazing fillings. At his shops in Brussels, Tokyo, New York, Kuwait City, London, and Paris, you can put together your own assortment of chocolates that are—with their array of colors—a treat for the eyes as well as the palate. If you can’t make it in person, Pierre also offers the option of [creating a custom assortment on his website](http://www.marcolini.be/#/en/eboutique/), for delivery around the world.

featureContentItems.seoTitle: 10 Chocolate Shops Worth Traveling For: La Maison du Chocolat, Mast Brothers, and More

fields.name: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell
fields.shortBio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell are food writers with a passion for seasonal food, great desserts, and inadvisable wine pairings. Read more on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net).
fields.bio: Elizabeth Stark and Brian Campbell have been chronicling their passion for simple, seasonal recipes since 2008 on their blog, [Brooklyn Supper](http://www.brooklynsupper.net). After almost a decade of life in Brooklyn, they recently moved with their family to the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Virginia where they live happily near the farmers and producers that inspire their work. Elizabeth is a regular contributor to Food52 where she writes the 'Salad Days' column. Her work has also appeared online on Saveur.com, Cosmopolitan.com, and People.com among others, and in print in *Vegetarian Times* magazine.

featureContentItems.hed: 7 Reasons to Make Mexico Your Next Romantic Getaway
featureContentItems.dek: From sexy boutique hotels to pristine white sand beaches, there are endless reasons why Mexico should be your next romantic getaway.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: 7 Reasons to Make Mexico Your Next Romantic Getaway
featureContentItems.seoDescription: From sexy boutique hotels to pristine white sand beaches, there are endless reasons why Mexico should be your next romantic getaway. Here are our top 7—just in time for Valentine's Day.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: 7 Reasons to Make Mexico Your Next Romantic Getaway
featureContentItems.socialDescription: From sexy boutique hotels to pristine white sand beaches, there are endless reasons why Mexico should be your next romantic getaway.

items.title: Intimacy
items.caption: In Tulum, you’ll find quiet, intimate, Crusoe-like escapes that’ll make you feel like you’re on your own private Caribbean island. Hole up at one of [Casa Violeta](http://www.casavioletatulum.com/)’s cozy beachfront bungalows nestled in the jungle, just steps from your own stretch of crystal clear ocean.

items.title: Sophisticated cuisine
items.caption: You might think Mexican food is all tacos, burritos, and enchiladas—and while there's nothing wrong with any of these, the cuisine south of the border has grown increasingly diverse, cosmopolitan, and totally date-worthy. Have a romantic dinner at [Pujol](http://www.pujol.com.mx/) in Mexico City, which offers innovative modern twists to traditional Mexican fare, or [Mar Plata](http://www.sanpancho.com/place/mar-plata/) in San Pancho, which offers exciting fusion cuisine in a rustic, intimate setting.

items.title: Sexy resorts
items.caption: Celebrities are often spotted holidaying in Mexico, and it’s no wonder: Luxe resorts like the [One & Only Palmilla](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/s--jose-del-cabo/one-only-palmilla--san-jose--del-cabo)—reportedly Jennifer Aniston’s favorite—offer the ease and tranquility of private island living, with all the luxe services and amenities of a five-star hotel. With their gorgeous spas and beautiful beachfront locations, [The Four Seasons Punta Mita](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/punta-de-mita/four-seasons-resort-punta-mita) and the [Imanta Resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/higuera-blanca/hotel-at-imanta-resort) are equally perfect for lighting or rekindling the flame.

items.title: World-class art
items.caption: The gorgeous, gallery-studded streets of Mexico City are great for romance. Neighborhoods like Roma and Condesa are home to small, sexy contemporary art museums perfect for exploring hand-in-hand. For easy access, set up shop at the sleek [Condesa DF](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/mexico/tacubaya/condesa-df), close to the [Galeria O.M.R.](http://www.galeriaomr.com/), which focuses on the work of emerging Mexican artists.

items.title: Natural beauty
items.caption: From the lush rainforests on Mexico's Pacific side, to the impossibly blue waters of the Mayan Riviera, you’ll find no better backdrop for falling in love.

items.title: Mezcal
items.caption: Skip the dive bars and head to one of the intimate, classy *mezcalerias* that have opened up all over Mexico City. Sip on spirits made by small local producers or on pretty, artfully-crafted mezcal-based cocktails. Head to [Corazón de Maguey](http://www.corazondemaguey.com/), in the heart of Coyoacán, or [La Botica](http://labotica.com.mx/), which supports only small producers from marginalized parts of the country, for a low-key, romantic nightcap.

items.title: Sunsets
items.caption: The long, dramatic sunsets in the Mayan Riviera are best enjoyed on the ocean, so hire a board from [Puerto Vallarta Surfing](http://www.puertovallartatours.net/surfing.htm), spend a day playing in the waves, and watch the sun sink slowly into the horizon beyond.

fields.name: Ondine Cohane
fields.shortBio: Contributing editor [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) is based in Tuscany—when not doing a round-the-world trip each winter.
fields.bio: After [Ondine Cohane](www.ondinecohane.com) edited *Conde Nast Traveler's* Word of Mouth section for a couple of years, she got her dream job, a gig as a contributing editor at the magazine. Eating great food, drinking excellent wine, discovering small hotels, exploring far-flung destinations are all part of the gig, and what she loves. Ondine was previously at *New York* magazine, and frequently writes for *The New York Times* travel section as well as *Lonny, Details,* and other magazines. Before Columbia College and Brearley, Ondine's family moved every couple of years, which may partially explain the wanderlust.

featureContentItems.hed: Gold List 2015: Hotels That Smell As Good As They Look
featureContentItems.dek: They say that scent is the strongest sense tied to memory, so it's no wonder we can't forget these [Gold List](http://www.cntraveler.com/reports/gold-list-2015) hotels. From cedarwood to signature candles, the fragrances of these properties stayed with us well after check-out.

items.title: [House of Jasmines, Salta](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/la-merced-chica/house-of-jasmines)
items.caption: Most romantic hotel ever: [House of Jasmines](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/la-merced-chica/house-of-jasmines), in Salta, Argentina. Everything smells deliciously of, yes, flowering jasmine, and there are roses in every room.*—Hanya Yanagihara*

items.title: [Ojai Valley Inn & Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/ojai/ojai-valley-inn---spa)
items.caption: Walk around the [Ojai Valley Inn and Spa](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/ojai/ojai-valley-inn---spa) at dusk: The air is perfumed with lavender, which is planted everywhere.*—John Wogan*
items.credit: Photo courtesy Ojai Valley Inn and Spa

items.title: [J.K. Place, Florence](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/j--k--place--florence)
items.caption: The [J.K. Place](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/italy/scandicci/j--k--place--florence) hotel in Florence has a signature amber scent as distinct as the city itself.*—Maria Schollenberger*

items.title: [Coqui Coqui, Tulum](https://cntraveler.com/hotels/tulum/coqui-coqui-tulum)
items.caption: There’s much not to love about [Coqui Coqui, Tulum](https://cntraveler.com/hotels/tulum/coqui-coqui-tulum): the staff, while sweet, is spacey. The crowd is douchey. The rooms are very, very dark and you can’t flush anything down the toilet. But I’d go back again because it smells so wonderful: a mix of agave, rose heart, and yucca. This is, of course, because of the hotel’s scent and candle line, all created at their own perfumery, and all of which somehow capture the smells of the Meixcan coast: earth, sea, flowers, cactus, and sky.*—H.Y.*

items.title: [Deetjan’s Big Sur Inn](https://cntraveler.com/hotels/big-sur/deetjens-big-sur-inn)
items.caption: [Deetjan’s in Big Sur](https://cntraveler.com/hotels/big-sur/deetjens-big-sur-inn) smells like juniper and pine everywhere you go and you can grab your own wood to build a fire in your room. *—Jenny Westerhoff*
items.credit: Photo courtesy Deetjen's Big Sur Inn

items.title: [Gramercy Park Hotel, New York City](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/gramercy-park-hotel)
items.caption:
Le Labo fragrances have become as synonymous with New York as the [Gramercy Park Hotel](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/gramercy-park-hotel), which boasts its own signature candle by the esteemed perfumery. It's called Cade 26, and its smoky, heady scent offers the same sense of nostalgia as the baroque-inspired hotel.*—M.S.*

*For more of the best hotels of 2015, check out our official [Gold List special report](http://cntraveler.com/reports/gold-list-2015).*

featureContentItems.hed: An Insider's View of the Grand Canyon
featureContentItems.dek: Here are the best South Rim trails, lookouts, and sights most tourists miss, according to Martin Behr of National Parks Revealed.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: An Insider's View of the Grand Canyon
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Here are the best South Rim trails, lookouts, and sights most tourists miss, according to Martin Behr of National Parks Revealed.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: An Insider's View of the Grand Canyon
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Here are the best South Rim trails, lookouts, and sights most tourists miss, according to Martin Behr of National Parks Revealed.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2f57edddaa35c30f66d46]||||||

Here are the best South Rim trails, lookouts, and sights most tourists miss, according to Martin Behr of [National Parks Revealed:](http://nationalparksrevealed.com/)

[#image: /photos/53e2f580c2d3f39d3610c0d9]||||||

1. **The Hermit Trail** leads into the canyon and is a great alternative to the much busier Bright Angel and South Kaibab trails.



2. **Hopi Point** is a popular place for summer sunsets, but venture about five and a half miles west to **Hermits Rest** for smaller crowds.



3. The easy-to-hike **Rim Trail **from Kolb Studio to Maricopa Point allows a moment of solitude at dawn or sunset.



4. The small but excellent **Tusayan Museum**, just south of Desert View Drive, exhibits 4,000-year-old artifacts.



5. **Navajo Point** is 24 miles from Grand Canyon Village, but go for the stellar views, particularly at sunrise and sunset. At 7,498 feet above sea level, it’s the highest spot along the South Rim.







**Read on for more [National Park Views Not to Be Missed.](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/03/national-parks-views-photos-yellowstone)**

featureContentItems.hed: The Ultimate Carry-On Guide for Guys
featureContentItems.dek: All the essentials items a man needs to stay comfortable and stylish on his next flight.
featureContentItems.body:
Whether you’re off for business or pleasure, traveling can be a stressful thing if you’re not properly prepared. When it comes to packing for your trip, your actual wardrobe will naturally vary depending on your destination. But when it comes to what to wear and bring onto the plane, I’ve come to adopt a basic uniform that has alleviated any pre-flight anxiety. This is geared specifically for guys, but aside from the clothing, the rest is totally applicable to the ladies as well. Here’s what I always have on my carry-on:

[#image: /photos/540f97ea17e4b1f634eefa2c]||||||

1) If you’re only going on a short trip (1–3 days), I’ve found this multifunctional bag by Qwstion to be the perfect solution. It's not too big, not too small, and fits with ease in the overhead compartment. It comes with an attached padded sleeve inside for a 15-inch laptop or tablet, and it even includes a separate shoe bag. The best part is this bag not only acts as a duffle, but it can also convert to a backpack as well. *[QWSTION](http://www.qwstion.com/us/bags/weekender-washed-black.html), $310*.

2) In addition to the carry-on bag, I also bring a small tote that has a shoulder strap. It's just convenient to have another bag where you can throw magazines, snacks, a tablet, etc. This L.L. Bean Field Canvas tote is great because it's not too wide and has a zipper so everything stays inside when you throw it underneath the seat in front of you. You don’t have to fuss with any buckles or straps. *[L.L. Bean](http://www.llbean.com/llb/shop/81519?feat=677-GN1&page=field-canvas-tote-bag), $89*.

When it comes to my travel outfit, I usually stick with solids and monochromatic/dark colors. Solids are preferable because they don’t leave as strong a visual impression as something with a print, and that’s helpful when you want to minimize what you bring and re-wear certain pieces. 


3) A black or white T-shirt is a perfect base layer. You can never go wrong if you start with the basics.  
*[RVCA](https://www.rvca.com/shop/product/mens-t-shirts/truck-patch?color=BLK), $27*.

4) Layering is key when it comes to travel. While a simple tee is my most comfortable go-to, I like to layer a long-sleeve, light blue button-down shirt on top. It works well in just about any circumstance. *[Quiksilver](http://www.quiksilver.com/allman-long-sleeve-shirt/qukuseqywt03030#selectedColor=bmc0&type=5), $49.50*.

5) You never know the climate conditions in airplanes and airports, so a lightweight jacket is always a good idea. This jacket by COS is a perfect example: It’s thin, made of a durable technical fabric, and walks a perfect fine line between casual (but not too casual) and just a bit fashion forward. *[COS](http://www.cosstores.com/us/Shop/Men/Coats_Jackets/Technical_zip-up_jacket/46909-15229657.1#c-15153035), $125*.

6) I prefer traveling in a nice broken-in pair of jeans, but ones that don't have holes, are too distressed, or have a light colored wash. Jeans are about as classic as it gets—as with the shirt mentioned above, you can easily dress them up depending on what you pair them with. *[Old Navy](http://oldnavy.gap.com/browse/product.do?cid=55506&vid=1&pid=776324022), $29.50*.


[#image: /photos/540f9808ade04e4d09bbc0fb]||||||


7) This is optional, but I also like to throw a very lightweight zip-up hoodie into my bag. These fold down really easily, don’t take up much space, and layer well underneath a jacket. In times when it suddenly gets super cold and windy, or if it’s raining and you didn’t pack an umbrella, an extra hoodie can be a lifesaver. *[J.Crew](https://www.jcrew.com/mens_category/teesfleece/Tops/PRDOVR~86607/86607.jsp?srcCode=PINT00003), $78*.

8)  I think most of us dread going through the security line, and although some airports no longer require you to take off your shoes, most still do. Slip-on shoes are the best solution. They are also good because your feet tend to expand once you're 30,000 feet in the air, and slip-ons will expand with them. *[Vans](http://www.vans.com/shop/perf-leather-slip-on-shoes), $60*.

9) For some reason, I have the unfortunate luck of always ending next to the row with the screaming child or loud talker. That's why noise-canceling headphones are a godsend. They might be expensive, but they are well worth the investment for the bit of solace and sanity on every flight. I like these earbuds from Bose—they are less bulky but still as powerful as a full-sized pair. *[Bose QuietComfort 20i](http://www.bose.com/controller?url=/shop_online/headphones/noise_cancelling_headphones/index.jsp), $299.95*.

10) There’s nothing worse than reaching for your phone or tablet and seeing your battery indicator in the red. It’s a good idea to bring an extra battery charger. This one by Fluxmob can double as your wall charger (so that’s one less thing to bring) and converts to an extra on-the-go battery charger. Just remember to pack the original cable your phone or tablet came with. *[Fluxmob](http://www.fluxmob.com/products/bolt-argon), $59.99*.

11) After being on the plane for a few hours, the constant recycled air can wreak havoc on your skin. These individually wrapped face wipes are an easy way to stay refreshed and look sharp right out of the gate. *[Ursa Major (box of 20)](http://www.ursamajorvt.com/products/essential-face-wipes), $24*.

12) I like to throw an immune system supplement and a couple bags of ginger or peppermint tea into my carry-on. With all the weird things you’re exposed to in airplanes and airports, its just nice to have a little healthy backup. Just in case. *[Emergen-C (box of 30)](http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss_1?url=search-alias=aps&field%20keywords=emergen%20c&sprefix=emergen%20c,aps&rh=i:aps,k:emergen%20c) Emergen-C (box of 30), $12.69*.

13) Finally, if nothing else, a good pair of shades is *essential*. You are an international jet-setting man of mystery, after all—right, Mr. Bond? *[Westward Leaning](http://westwardleaning.com/products/color-revolution-9-22-blue-mirror-wayfarer), $210*.

featureContentItems.hed: What It Takes to Be an "Engagement Concierge"
featureContentItems.dek: Planning to pop the question this Valentine’s Day? Some hotels, like the Westin Hilton Head, now have staff members whose job is to help make a proposal more memorable.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/54cfe2989abb8d533165d3d2]||||||





What’s more romantic than whisking someone away to an island retreat and then proposing? Very little, which is why the staff at the [Westin Hilton Head](http://www.westinhiltonheadisland.com/) in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, employs “engagement concierges” whose job is to help facilitate proposals—whether that means sourcing the perfect flowers, choosing the right restaurant, or getting "bystanders" in on the surprise. *Condé Nast Traveler* spoke with Ellen Lam, the hotel's leisure sales manager, who oversees the engagement concierge program, to get the dirt on what it takes to pull off the perfect proposal.

__First things first—when someone asks you to help with their proposal, what does that usually entail?__

Sometimes [the request for help] happens in advance when the couple makes the reservation. One of them will usually reach out to us and let us know what they're planning and look for ideas that we can provide them. But sometimes it's spur of the moment, and we have to find jewelers on the island. The planning that happens in advance is more about the *where*—where are the most romantic spots, the best tables at restaurants, that kind of thing. 

Once they get here, we get involved in the *what*: Where can we hide the ring, what place will have the fewest people. We get into the nuts and bolts of what's going to happen. We have four or five restaurants here on the island that we really recommend because not only do they have the right ambiance but the management is fun to work with and in tune with orchestrating these kinds of happenings.

__Why do you think Hilton Head is such a popular proposal spot? Is it just the appeal of being on the beach and getting away from it all?__

We have a unique ambiance here on Hilton Head. It's hard to think of a resort that has so resisted the siren call of development. There are no neon lights or streetlights, no commercial signage over five feet or buildings taller than the trees. As part of that, we want people to enjoy the unique scenes we have here. It's a beautiful, unspoiled environment.

__Have you had any unusual or difficult requests?__

The most unusual one we've had was a guest who asked us to hide the ring in an oyster shell, on an oyster bank, in the creek. That was major stress to make sure this thing was well handled. We partner with a local adventure company called [Outside Hilton Head](http://www.outsidehiltonhead.com/), so we reached out to them and they were able to tell us when the tides were on the day he wanted to propose, since that made a big difference. They went out in advance and placed the ring in the oyster on the oyster bank, then the couple had a guided kayak tour and [the guide] took them to the oyster bank, and there were dolphins playing around them, and the guide was in on it and encouraged the woman to reach out and pick up the oyster. It actually went off beautifully. We were trying to get a drone to videotape it!

We had a woman say no! It was not good because the engagement concierge did not know the outcome, just where it was and the backdrop. She called the guy the next morning to make sure it all went according to plan, and obviously he was very emotional about it. The guy wanted to have people in the water on stand up paddleboards as a backdrop for the photo, so we arranged all of that, and then she said no.

__What if a couple gets engaged on the property without asking someone from the hotel to be involved? Is there anything special you can do for them?__

We had an LGBT couple here get engaged in October. We have a package where if you buy three rooms you get a suite for one of them so everybody has a place to hang out. We had a group of guys here for a getaway, and they had an oceanfront cabana they had rented. They did the proposal out there—they called room service to get champagne, so that's how we found out about it, and we sent it up for free. 

__About how many proposals happen at the resort?__

[Our outgoing concierge] was in the job for a year, and she had 34 proposals she had worked on and helped plan in her first year of the program. Our restaurant director, who is kind of a young, gregarious, fun-loving guy, has been involved in a number of other ones where people come to, say, our oceanfront bar and let the server know that they might need a bottle of champagne. The server lets Freddy, our RD, know, and he engages with the guy (or girl!) and sees if there's anything special they can do.

featureContentItems.hed: HotelsByDay Will Offer Mid-Day Hotel Stays—But Will Travelers Use It?
featureContentItems.dek: HotelsByDay is targeting travelers looking for a quiet place to work, nap, or refresh, as well as locals looking for a nearby getaway. But will the four-hour hotel stay ever really catch on?
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53dac1ca6dec627b14a00920]|||
Would you book a hotel room for just four hours?
|||





[HotelsByDay](https://www.hotelsbyday.com/), a service that claims to be the first to allow travelers to instantly book mid-day rather than overnight hotel stays, launches today. The startup offers morning, mid-day, or afternoon stays of four to eight hours at 40 different hotels in Chicago, New York, Philadelphia, and Washington, D.C. The company plans to add Fort Lauderdale, Los Angeles, Miami, and other cities soon.

HotelsByDay says it's targeting travelers looking for a quiet place to work, nap, or refresh, as well as locals looking for a getaway in their home city. It could also appeal to business people who prefer a quiet room to a coffee shop, travelers who crave a shower upon landing, or people wanting to take advantage of a hotel’s fitness facilities. To me, it sounded like a good option to leave behind the distractions of my D.C.-area home and get some work done. So when HotelsByDay offered a preview ahead of the launch, I accepted.

Using the HotelsByDay website will be familiar to anyone who's booked a room online. So far, though, the only Washington, D.C. accommodation available is at the Capitol Skyline Hotel, which I booked. In a location where more options are available—most of the current offerings are in Chicago and New York—travelers can browse them all by location, time available, cost, and amenities. Rooms are for two guests, and check-out time is not flexible, which is no surprise given the nature of the service. (While none of the participating hotels are giving rewards points for intra-day stays yet, HotelsByDay is looking to partner with hoteliers in that area.)

My five-hour intra-day stay was $90 before tax. That was also the lowest rate I was able to find online for an overnight stay at the Capitol Skyline Hotel, checking in the night before my visit. On my stay, I was able to use the room from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m.; had I spent the night, checkout time would've been noon. Some people may prefer the quiet of a hotel room to alternatives like simply working in a local coffee shop, but the cost of a $90 room compared to a $3 coffee may limit the appeal of HotelsByDay to those with flexible expense accounts.

featureContentItems.seoDescription: HotelsByDay is targeting travelers looking for a quiet place to work, nap, or refresh, as well as locals looking for a nearby getaway. But will the four-hour hotel stay ever really catch on?

fields.title: [Wythe Hotel](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/wythe-hotel-brooklyn-new-york)
fields.caption: A converted turn-of-the-century factory with 72 rooms, a rooftop bar, and a stand-out restaurant. The hotel is one block from the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg, a once-industrial neighborhood transformed by artists, entrepreneurs, and a new wave of immigrants. fields.bio:
Zach Everson is a Washington, D.C.-based freelance writer, focusing on travel and food. He has contributed to *The Wall Street Journal*, Air Canada's *enRoute*, *USA Today* and Eater. When traveling he's usually looking for Caravaggios, bourbon-based cocktails, and restaurants with
cheese carts.
